documents: 17-year-old male (52 kg, O+) presents with 4 days of URI symptoms (sore throat, rhinorrhea improving) and productive cough; noted scant hemoptysis today (~1 teaspoon total, bright red streaks, no clots), low-grade fever 37.8°C, mild exertional dyspnea, dull cough-associated non-pleuritic chest pain. No weight loss, night sweats, epistaxis, gum bleeding, easy bruising. Non-smoker, no vaping, no known TB contacts; classmate with cough last week; no recent travel. Medications tried: paracetamol 500 mg x2, OTC dextromethorphan x2. Provisional diagnosis: Acute bronchitis/upper respiratory infection with scant hemoptysis from airway irritation; pneumonia and pulmonary tuberculosis lower-likelihood but to be excluded with imaging and persistence criteria. Differential: acute bronchitis/viral URI; bacterial pneumonia (consider if fever escalates or focal findings); pulmonary tuberculosis (rule out if persistent or abnormal CXR); posterior epistaxis mimicking hemoptysis; less likely bronchiectasis/foreign body/coagulopathy. Recommended investigations: Chest X-ray (PA/LAT) now; CBC with platelets; consider PT/INR/aPTT if bleeding disorder suspected; sputum studies if purulent sputum and fever persist; TB workup (AFB/NAAT, IGRA/TST) if CXR abnormal or symptoms persist. Initial management: Supportive care (hydration, rest, humidified air), cautious antitussive use, avoid NSAIDs; no routine antibiotics unless pneumonia suspected clinically or on CXR. Safety-net: escalate for large-volume hemoptysis, worsening dyspnea, hypoxia, high fever, syncope, chest pain at rest, instability. Follow-up: 48–72 hours to review CXR/labs; if hemoptysis persists >1 week or recurs, consider contrast-enhanced chest CT and pulmonology/ENT evaluation.

28-year-old female presents with 3 weeks of episodic wheeze, chest tightness, and nocturnal cough, worse with exercise and dust exposure; partial relief with friend’s salbutamol inhaler. No fever, chest pain, or hemoptysis. Past history notable for childhood atopy (eczema); non-smoker. Exam between episodes is normal; peak flow variable at home (350–420 L/min). Provisional diagnosis: Asthma (mild persistent). Differential: exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, allergic rhinitis with post-nasal drip, GERD-related cough. Recommended investigations: Spirometry with bronchodilator reversibility; consider FeNO and allergy testing. Initial management: Inhaled low-dose ICS with as-needed SABA; trigger avoidance and spacer technique education; action plan with peak-flow zones. Follow-up: 2–4 weeks to assess control and adherence; step-up if persistent symptoms.

6-month-old male with 2 days of cough, rhinorrhea, poor feeding, and increasing work of breathing; exam shows tachypnea, subcostal retractions, nasal flaring, diffuse crackles and wheeze; SpO2 90% on room air. No prior wheeze episodes. Provisional diagnosis: Acute bronchiolitis (likely RSV). Differential: viral pneumonia, early asthma phenotype (less likely at this age), bacterial pneumonia (if focal consolidation). Recommended investigations: Pulse oximetry; CXR only if severe/atypical; viral testing if needed for cohorting. Initial management: Oxygen to maintain SpO2 ≥ 92%, nasal suctioning, hydration support; avoid routine bronchodilators/steroids unless trial beneficial. Escalation: Worsening hypoxia, apnea, exhaustion, dehydration. Follow-up: Inpatient observation if oxygen requirement persists; otherwise close outpatient follow-up within 24–48 hours.

64-year-old male with 3 months of exertional chest pressure (5–10 min, relieved by rest), associated with dyspnea; risk factors include hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and 30-pack-year smoking history (quit 5 years ago). No rest pain or syncope. Exam unremarkable; resting ECG normal. Provisional diagnosis: Stable angina (chronic coronary syndrome). Differential: GERD, musculoskeletal chest pain, anxiety/panic, microvascular angina. Recommended investigations: Stress test (exercise ECG or imaging), lipid panel, A1c; consider coronary CT angiography if intermediate risk. Initial management: Antiplatelet (aspirin unless contraindicated), statin (high-intensity), sublingual nitroglycerin PRN; optimize BP, glycemic control, lifestyle. Red flags: Rest pain >20 min, hemodynamic instability → urgent evaluation.

22-year-old female presents with dysuria, urinary frequency, and suprapubic discomfort for 2 days; afebrile; no flank pain, no vaginal discharge. Sexually active; uses condoms inconsistently. Provisional diagnosis: Uncomplicated acute cystitis. Differential: urethritis (STI), vaginitis, early pyelonephritis (if fever/flank pain develop). Recommended investigations: Urinalysis and urine culture (culture optional if classic presentation); consider NAAT for chlamydia/gonorrhea if urethritis suspected. Initial management: Empiric nitrofurantoin 100 mg BID x5 days (if no contraindications) or fosfomycin single dose; phenazopyridine short-term for dysuria. Red flags: Fever, flank pain, vomiting, pregnancy, immunocompromised state → broaden workup.

45-year-old male with polyuria, polydipsia, unintentional weight loss over 3 months; random plasma glucose 246 mg/dL and HbA1c 8.6%. No DKA symptoms. BMI 29; family history of diabetes. Provisional diagnosis: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. Differential: LADA (consider if lean/autoimmune), medication-induced hyperglycemia, Cushing’s. Recommended investigations: Fasting glucose, repeat A1c, lipid panel, eGFR, urine albumin-to-creatinine, liver enzymes; consider autoantibodies if atypical. Initial management: Metformin (if eGFR adequate), lifestyle modification, SMBG; vaccinate per guidelines; ASCVD risk reduction (statin). Follow-up: 3 months for A1c; earlier if hypoglycemia or intolerance.

34-year-old female with episodic right upper quadrant pain after fatty meals, radiating to back, associated with nausea; afebrile; Murphy sign equivocal; labs pending. Prior similar episodes x3 months. Provisional diagnosis: Symptomatic cholelithiasis (biliary colic). Differential: acute cholecystitis (if fever/WBC, persistent RUQ tenderness), peptic ulcer disease, pancreatitis, hepatic causes. Recommended investigations: RUQ ultrasound (gallstones, wall thickening, CBD), LFTs, lipase. Initial management: Analgesia, low-fat diet; surgical consult for elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy if symptomatic stones confirmed. Red flags: Fever, jaundice, persistent severe pain → evaluate for cholecystitis/choledocholithiasis.

8-year-old male with itchy, erythematous, scaly patches on antecubital fossae and popliteal areas; intermittent flares, worse with heat and soap; family history of atopy. No fever; no purulent drainage. Provisional diagnosis: Atopic dermatitis. Differential: contact dermatitis, psoriasis, tinea corporis (if annular), impetiginization (if crusting). Recommended investigations: Usually clinical; KOH scraping if tinea suspected. Initial management: Regular emollients, topical low-to-medium potency corticosteroids for flares, trigger avoidance (fragrances, harsh soaps), antihistamine at night if pruritus disrupts sleep. Follow-up: Education on steroid use; escalate to calcineurin inhibitors if steroid-sparing needed.

72-year-old female with acute onset facial droop on the left, slurred speech, and right arm weakness lasting 30 minutes, resolved on arrival; BP 168/92; on antihypertensives inconsistently. Provisional diagnosis: Transient ischemic attack (TIA). Differential: migraine aura, focal seizure, hypoglycemia, Bell’s palsy (if isolated facial involvement). Recommended investigations: Urgent brain imaging (MRI with DWI preferred or CT), vascular imaging (carotid/CTA/MRA), ECG and rhythm monitoring, glucose, lipids. Initial management: Antiplatelet therapy after imaging excludes hemorrhage; BP, statin, and risk factor control; admit/observe based on risk stratification (ABCD2). Red flags: Persistent deficits or hemorrhage signs → stroke code.

23-year-old with unilateral left-eye redness and mild itching for 2 days; no discharge, no pain, no photophobia, no vision changes; seasonal allergy history. Provisional diagnosis: Allergic conjunctivitis. Differential: viral conjunctivitis (less likely without watery discharge or preauricular node), bacterial conjunctivitis (unlikely without purulent discharge), dry eye/irritant exposure. Plan: Cold compresses, lubricating drops, oral or topical antihistamine/mast-cell stabilizer; return if pain, photophobia, decreased vision, or discharge develops.

25-year-old male presents with cough, fever, and body ache for several days; reports feeling unwell with systemic symptoms, body temperature elevated to 39.2°C, heart rate 90 bpm, blood pressure 161/81, oxygen saturation 93%. Physical examination shows signs of viral illness with no focal respiratory findings. No complications noted. Provisional diagnosis: Flu. Differential: viral upper respiratory infection, seasonal influenza, early pneumonia (if chest findings develop), COVID-19 (pending testing). Plan: Supportive care with rest, adequate hydration, antipyretics for fever management, symptomatic treatment for comfort. Monitor for complications. Return if worsening dyspnea, persistent high fever >3 days, or signs of secondary bacterial infection. Severity: moderate presentation requiring medication and rest.

Overall appears well. Provisional diagnosis: Healthy. Differential: viral prodrome, mild dehydration, stress-related symptoms, early viral illness, non-specific malaise. Plan: Reassurance and supportive care, adequate rest and hydration, symptom monitoring. Return for evaluation if symptoms progress or new concerning features develop. Severity: mild presentation requiring rest and fluids.

20-year-old male presents with headache, cough, and runny nose for several days; persistent productive cough, temperature 37.2°C, heart rate 87 bpm, blood pressure 112/75, oxygen saturation 92% below normal. Clinical presentation suggests lower respiratory tract involvement. Provisional diagnosis: Bronchitis. Differential: acute bronchitis, pneumonia (if fever and consolidation), asthma exacerbation, COPD exacerbation (if history), whooping cough. Plan: Bronchodilators if wheezing present, supportive care, adequate hydration, cough suppressants if dry cough interfering with sleep. Antibiotics only if bacterial superinfection suspected. Hospitalization and medication required given severity. Severity: severe presentation requiring hospitalization and medication.

26-year-old male presents with fever, headache, and runny nose for several days; mild upper respiratory symptoms, low-grade temperature 36.2°C, stable vital signs with heart rate 61 bpm, blood pressure 152/71, good oxygen saturation 96%. Self-limited viral illness pattern. Provisional diagnosis: Cold. Differential: common cold (rhinovirus), allergic rhinitis, early influenza, sinusitis (if facial pain/pressure develops). Plan: Conservative management with rest, increased fluid intake, humidified air, saline nasal rinses. Symptomatic relief with decongestants if needed. Expected resolution within 7-10 days. Severity: mild presentation requiring rest and fluids.

Physical exam may reveal crackles, bronchial breathing, or dullness to percussion. Provisional diagnosis: Pneumonia. doc_metadata.condition: Acute bronchitis with scant hemoptysis (rule out pneumonia/TB)

chunks: 17-year-old male (52 kg, O+) presents with 4 days of URI symptoms (sore throat, rhinorrhea improving) and productive cough; noted scant hemoptysis today (~1 teaspoon total, bright red streaks, no clots), low-grade fever 37.8°C, mild exertional dyspnea, dull cough-associated non-pleuritic chest pain. No weight loss, night sweats, epistaxis, gum bleeding, easy bruising. Non-smoker, no vaping, no known TB contacts; classmate with cough last week; no recent travel. Medications tried: paracetamol 500 mg x2, OTC dextromethorphan x2. Provisional diagnosis: Acute bronchitis/upper respiratory infection with scant hemoptysis from airway irritation; pneumonia and pulmonary tuberculosis lower-likelihood but to be excluded with imaging and persistence criteria. Differential: acute bronchitis/viral URI; bacterial pneumonia (consider if fever escalates or focal findings); pulmonary tuberculosis (rule out if persistent or abnormal CXR); posterior epistaxis mimicking hemoptysis; less likely bronchiectasis/foreign body/coagulopathy. Recommended investigations: Chest X-ray (PA/LAT) now; CBC with platelets; consider PT/INR/aPTT if bleeding disorder suspected; sputum studies if purulent sputum and fever persist; TB workup (AFB/NAAT, IGRA/TST) if CXR abnormal or symptoms persist. Initial management: Supportive care (hydration, rest, humidified air), cautious antitussive use, avoid NSAIDs; no routine antibiotics unless pneumonia suspected clinically or on CXR. Safety-net: escalate for large-volume hemoptysis, worsening dyspnea, hypoxia, high fever, syncope, chest pain at rest, instability. Follow-up: 48–72 hours to review CXR/labs; if hemoptysis persists >1 week or recurs, consider contrast-enhanced chest CT and pulmonology/ENT evaluation.

28-year-old female presents with 3 weeks of episodic wheeze, chest tightness, and nocturnal cough, worse with exercise and dust exposure; partial relief with friend’s salbutamol inhaler. No fever, chest pain, or hemoptysis. Past history notable for childhood atopy (eczema); non-smoker. Exam between episodes is normal; peak flow variable at home (350–420 L/min). Provisional diagnosis: Asthma (mild persistent). Differential: exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, allergic rhinitis with post-nasal drip, GERD-related cough. Recommended investigations: Spirometry with bronchodilator reversibility; consider FeNO and allergy testing. Initial management: Inhaled low-dose ICS with as-needed SABA; trigger avoidance and spacer technique education; action plan with peak-flow zones. Follow-up: 2–4 weeks to assess control and adherence; step-up if persistent symptoms.

6-month-old male with 2 days of cough, rhinorrhea, poor feeding, and increasing work of breathing; exam shows tachypnea, subcostal retractions, nasal flaring, diffuse crackles and wheeze; SpO2 90% on room air. No prior wheeze episodes. Provisional diagnosis: Acute bronchiolitis (likely RSV). Differential: viral pneumonia, early asthma phenotype (less likely at this age), bacterial pneumonia (if focal consolidation). Recommended investigations: Pulse oximetry; CXR only if severe/atypical; viral testing if needed for cohorting. Initial management: Oxygen to maintain SpO2 ≥ 92%, nasal suctioning, hydration support; avoid routine bronchodilators/steroids unless trial beneficial. Escalation: Worsening hypoxia, apnea, exhaustion, dehydration. Follow-up: Inpatient observation if oxygen requirement persists; otherwise close outpatient follow-up within 24–48 hours.

64-year-old male with 3 months of exertional chest pressure (5–10 min, relieved by rest), associated with dyspnea; risk factors include hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and 30-pack-year smoking history (quit 5 years ago). No rest pain or syncope. Exam unremarkable; resting ECG normal. Provisional diagnosis: Stable angina (chronic coronary syndrome). Differential: GERD, musculoskeletal chest pain, anxiety/panic, microvascular angina. Recommended investigations: Stress test (exercise ECG or imaging), lipid panel, A1c; consider coronary CT angiography if intermediate risk. Initial management: Antiplatelet (aspirin unless contraindicated), statin (high-intensity), sublingual nitroglycerin PRN; optimize BP, glycemic control, lifestyle. Red flags: Rest pain >20 min, hemodynamic instability → urgent evaluation.

22-year-old female presents with dysuria, urinary frequency, and suprapubic discomfort for 2 days; afebrile; no flank pain, no vaginal discharge. Sexually active; uses condoms inconsistently. Provisional diagnosis: Uncomplicated acute cystitis. Differential: urethritis (STI), vaginitis, early pyelonephritis (if fever/flank pain develop). Recommended investigations: Urinalysis and urine culture (culture optional if classic presentation); consider NAAT for chlamydia/gonorrhea if urethritis suspected. Initial management: Empiric nitrofurantoin 100 mg BID x5 days (if no contraindications) or fosfomycin single dose; phenazopyridine short-term for dysuria. Red flags: Fever, flank pain, vomiting, pregnancy, immunocompromised state → broaden workup.

45-year-old male with polyuria, polydipsia, unintentional weight loss over 3 months; random plasma glucose 246 mg/dL and HbA1c 8.6%. No DKA symptoms. BMI 29; family history of diabetes. Provisional diagnosis: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. Differential: LADA (consider if lean/autoimmune), medication-induced hyperglycemia, Cushing’s. Recommended investigations: Fasting glucose, repeat A1c, lipid panel, eGFR, urine albumin-to-creatinine, liver enzymes; consider autoantibodies if atypical. Initial management: Metformin (if eGFR adequate), lifestyle modification, SMBG; vaccinate per guidelines; ASCVD risk reduction (statin). Follow-up: 3 months for A1c; earlier if hypoglycemia or intolerance.

34-year-old female with episodic right upper quadrant pain after fatty meals, radiating to back, associated with nausea; afebrile; Murphy sign equivocal; labs pending. Prior similar episodes x3 months. Provisional diagnosis: Symptomatic cholelithiasis (biliary colic). Differential: acute cholecystitis (if fever/WBC, persistent RUQ tenderness), peptic ulcer disease, pancreatitis, hepatic causes. Recommended investigations: RUQ ultrasound (gallstones, wall thickening, CBD), LFTs, lipase. Initial management: Analgesia, low-fat diet; surgical consult for elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy if symptomatic stones confirmed. Red flags: Fever, jaundice, persistent severe pain → evaluate for cholecystitis/choledocholithiasis.

8-year-old male with itchy, erythematous, scaly patches on antecubital fossae and popliteal areas; intermittent flares, worse with heat and soap; family history of atopy. No fever; no purulent drainage. Provisional diagnosis: Atopic dermatitis. Differential: contact dermatitis, psoriasis, tinea corporis (if annular), impetiginization (if crusting). Recommended investigations: Usually clinical; KOH scraping if tinea suspected. Initial management: Regular emollients, topical low-to-medium potency corticosteroids for flares, trigger avoidance (fragrances, harsh soaps), antihistamine at night if pruritus disrupts sleep. Follow-up: Education on steroid use; escalate to calcineurin inhibitors if steroid-sparing needed.

72-year-old female with acute onset facial droop on the left, slurred speech, and right arm weakness lasting 30 minutes, resolved on arrival; BP 168/92; on antihypertensives inconsistently. Provisional diagnosis: Transient ischemic attack (TIA). Differential: migraine aura, focal seizure, hypoglycemia, Bell’s palsy (if isolated facial involvement). Recommended investigations: Urgent brain imaging (MRI with DWI preferred or CT), vascular imaging (carotid/CTA/MRA), ECG and rhythm monitoring, glucose, lipids. Initial management: Antiplatelet therapy after imaging excludes hemorrhage; BP, statin, and risk factor control; admit/observe based on risk stratification (ABCD2). Red flags: Persistent deficits or hemorrhage signs → stroke code.

23-year-old with unilateral left-eye redness and mild itching for 2 days; no discharge, no pain, no photophobia, no vision changes; seasonal allergy history. Provisional diagnosis: Allergic conjunctivitis. Differential: viral conjunctivitis (less likely without watery discharge or preauricular node), bacterial conjunctivitis (unlikely without purulent discharge), dry eye/irritant exposure. Plan: Cold compresses, lubricating drops, oral or topical antihistamine/mast-cell stabilizer; return if pain, photophobia, decreased vision, or discharge develops.

25-year-old male presents with cough, fever, and body ache for several days; reports feeling unwell with systemic symptoms, body temperature elevated to 39.2°C, heart rate 90 bpm, blood pressure 161/81, oxygen saturation 93%. Physical examination shows signs of viral illness with no focal respiratory findings. No complications noted. Provisional diagnosis: Flu. Differential: viral upper respiratory infection, seasonal influenza, early pneumonia (if chest findings develop), COVID-19 (pending testing). Plan: Supportive care with rest, adequate hydration, antipyretics for fever management, symptomatic treatment for comfort. Monitor for complications. Return if worsening dyspnea, persistent high fever >3 days, or signs of secondary bacterial infection. Severity: moderate presentation requiring medication and rest.
